messageBody:
> 2. It is not uncommon that the methods of a
> class require a 'state' in order for them to be > called. and coming to this 'state' is often not
> an easy task.
 
Personally, I use my own small tool called testAssure to help me do fine grained unit testing.
 
The problem with arriving at the particular state is the information that is required to be set up... some of which is hidden in private state variables.  Instead of creating public get and set methods (ie. those that are only necessary during testing), the tool does the following....
 
1. It converts all private and protected variables and methods to public (for a particular directory) so that test methods can exploit this information to setup data.
 
2.  It "enables" the special tests in your test code so that they can be run (ie. I convert a private method to public and now my test code can use this information).
 
3. The system can undo all changes above..
 
The main advantage to this tool is that you can continue doing regular testing (ie everything works fine without running the tool), and when you are using the testAssure you can access the internal variables directly to do "real" unit testing.
 
The tool was developped as a proof of concept project last December, and I will be adding a more functional front end in March.
 
The concepts behind the tool are contained within a (as of yet not published) pattern language concerning in-line testing (similar to XP test-first, but less stringent on the notion of testing before you write code) as well as few ppt presentations.
 
andrew f
